posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: Does anyone do anything special to ensure they cut versatube in the right way so that when CNC machining features into it they are properly aligned with the pre-drilled holes? I’ve considered adding pin slots for alignment on the side / bottom but I’m also interested in what others are trying.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked: When laying flat (2" wide, 1" tall) I like to put a drill rod pin in the existing holes that then butts up against the vice to precisely indicate.

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: I’m not familiar with drill rod pins, and a cursory google / mcmaster search didn’t lead anywhere.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: I cannot speak for what Adam means. But McMaster Carr sales drill rod. Basically tight tolerance rod made of tool steel.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked:
3023A331

Adding words bc chief won’t let me post single words even though mcmaster part numbers without context are a novel.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
Dowel pins also work ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Really any pin/rod you can put in a rivet hole, and especially if you can chuck the pin into your spindle.

posts.name: Nicholas Dal Porto
posts.cooked: What does your work holding setup look like?

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: I have an Omio X6, team is potentially getting an X8. In the past I’ve used the ozzyboards tube magic on a different machine, and even further back I’ve used a pair of vices, but I’m open to whatever is easiest to index the versatubing with, since I’d like to use more of it, but would also like to add in some custom features if I can.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked:
Taking a step back I’d suggest not precision machining any features in predrill, and instead handle everything with 2d plates on it.

But you do you man.

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: I try to when I can, but every once in a while there’s a precision feature on a tube that would make life a whole lot easier. Also the 2x1 versatube doesn’t have holes on the 2" side and I really like using that side.

posts.name: This isn't a game. Think about the repercussions.
posts.cooked:
Or just get 2 x 1 tube and machine in your own holes. Even if you just chuck a 1/8" or 1/4" drill bit in the router, you can hand-drill them with a 17/64" bit later. Then you’re guaranteed (to the accuracy of the machine) proper alignment.

Our 2 x 1 machining fixture looks kinda like a wood 2 x 4 with slots (cut by the CNC) for the material. We use slightly longer material than needed so we can clamp the ends down.

For 2-sided machining, we add one or more locating holes (1/4") that align with a hole in the fixture, using a metal pin as noted further above. We also machine full-width slots in the ends so the length is perfect, and we just finish off the un-cut parts by hand.
posts.display_username: This isn't a game. Think about the repercussions.

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked:
DonRotolo:

Or just get 2 x 1 tube and machine in your own holes.

We used to do this. Wasted so much time on the holes. I’d really love to not.

posts.name: Nick Aarestad
posts.cooked: We’d love to not too but we’re committed to the # 10 thing and there aren’t any COTS patterned tubes with # 10 patterns so… we’re doing some work one way or the other.

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: I was just gonna drill out the ones we need. Easy enough and great way to teach new students how to use the drill press while still having them do something useful.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
DonRotolo:

Our 2 x 1 machining fixture looks kinda like a wood 2 x 4 with slots

Yeah, that’s us too. It solved fixture tolerancing process problems, which cost us something like 4 sets of drive rails one year, but takes f.o.r.e.vv.e.r.

Open question though, is this a problem that can get solved on the saw-to-length step instead? Add indexing pins with a fixture plate on a rage4, for example?

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: One of my original ideas was determining the thickness of the saw blade and making a jig that plugs into the holes on the one side and provides a hard stopped cutting edge for the saw. We use a couple different saws, though, of differing blade thicknesses, so I was hoping for a bit better of a “one size fits all” solution.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked:
I’ve been happy enough printing a block with pins that sites on the long side of the tube, and butts against the blade. No need to account for blade thickness (but be sure you’re touching the truth thickness of the blade on the teeth, not in the round center).

Align, clamp, remove block, cut… Holds within .02" easy.

973 rough cut all tubes, and then had a pin in the vice on a manual mill to index and face to length. 97.3% of tubes were a .5" offset for hole, so we’d zero once, lock the axis, and face 100+ tubes in a day with minimal skill/effort.

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: I like the method, but we don’t have a manual mill for facing. Aside from “get a mill”, how would you go about getting tubes to size then?

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked:
Same process could be done on a router.

Taking another step back, do you care about precision of end of tubes? As long as it’s not too long, it doesn’t matter in a tube-gusset ecosystem. IF the ends of your tubes are touching you are over constrained.

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked:
That’s sorta my train of thought with the jig alignment idea. Back when using the tubemagic fixture, I did care about the precision at the ends of the tubes, because we used the ends of the tube to zero our router’s position on the tube, so if the ends were off, then our positioning relative to the hole pattern on the other sides was off. I’m considering going with a vice setup instead, and using your drill rod idea to hold position in the vice, and just zero off the vice, so that way we’re the same position relative to the hole pattern, which is what I care about most.

Currently looking into vices I can put on my X6, if anyone has any suggestions I’d appreciate the input.
